headline.main: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; A Space Shuttle Rescue, After the Fact

results.snippet: IT would have looked a lot like something from a science fiction movie, but there could have been a rescue option for the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart on Feb. 1, according to a report released last week by the Columbia Accident...
results.lead_paragraph: IT would have looked a lot like something from a science fiction movie, but there could have been a rescue option for the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart on Feb. 1, according to a report released last week by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board. If NASA had recognized early on that the shuttle had been damaged at liftoff, the report said, it could have ordered the seven Columbia astronauts to conserve oxygen by minimizing all physical activity. The astronauts would have slept 8 hours a day, or maybe 12, and could have survived in orbit four weeks, instead of two.

results.abstract: Australian National University researchers report in journal Science that Iceman, alpine mummy, lived in valley region within 35 miles south of Tyrolean Alps site where he was found; gorgesaurus, being prepared for exhibit at Indianapolis Children's Museum, is found to have brain tumor; fossilized mass, which is first recognized evidence of brain tumor in dinosaur fossil, is confirmed by Black Hills Institute of Geological Research scientists with help of Indiana University radiologists; Columbia astronauts are added to astronaut memorial at Cape Canaveral; crew member Dr Kalpana Chawla's will donates $300,000 to establish Kalpana Chawla Fund for Environmental Stewardship through National Audubon Society; drawing (M)

keywords.name: organizations

results.snippet: An Iceman Close to Home      In 1991, when the world first encountered the Alpine mummy called the Iceman, he had melted out of the glacier that had encased him since the late Stone Age.    But if in death he had not gotten around much in 5,200...
results.lead_paragraph: An Iceman Close to Home In 1991, when the world first encountered the Alpine mummy called the Iceman, he had melted out of the glacier that had encased him since the late Stone Age. But if in death he had not gotten around much in 5,200 years, in life the Iceman was no slouch. For one thing, when he died, roughly at age 46, he was traveling at 10,500 feet through a high pass in the Tyrolean Alps, near the current border between Italy and Austria.

results.abstract: John Rockwell Reverberations column praises actors, musicians, artists, choreographers and writers who continue to make art every day despite remaining unrecognized; photo (M)

headline.main: To All of You Who Make Art for Its Own Sake: A Toast

results.snippet: Following the trails of friendship, either for young performers or their parents, I found myself recently at two events stocked with aspiring musicians and actors. One was a program of Spanish music by Spanish students at the Manhattan School of...
results.lead_paragraph: Following the trails of friendship, either for young performers or their parents, I found myself recently at two events stocked with aspiring musicians and actors. One was a program of Spanish music by Spanish students at the Manhattan School of Music; the other was an evening of three one-act plays by Horton Foote by second-year students at the Atlantic Theater Company Acting School. Both programs gave considerable pleasure; young talents abounded. What struck me, however, beyond all the gifted individuals, was their sheer numbers. All the time, all over Manhattan and the country and the world, there are similar performances of well-trained, gifted and ambitious young people, all making art. What will become of them?
